prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

para.paratext: When transfer is ordered by the Panel, the transferee court is vested with jurisdiction over the actions. The transfer order becomes effective when it is filed with the Clerk of District Court in the transferee district.[1] When filing takes place in the transferee court the change of jurisdiction is complete; nothing further need be done by the Panel, the transferee court, or the transferor court in order to effect transfer of jurisdiction.[2]

When transfer is ordered, further proceedings take place in the transferee court just as if the actions had been filed there. The nature and extent of the proceedings in the transferee court are discussed in Chapter 9.

The mechanics of transferring the physical court files, as opposed to the legal authority, to the transferee court can be difficult. The transferee court and transferor courts are notified of the Panel's transfer order simultaneously. The Panel Rules require transferor courts to transfer “the record of each transferred action to the transferee district.”[3] Because of the potentially massive burdens this rule imposes in MDL dockets involving large numbers of cases, the Panel has expressly exempted actions from it.[4] In those cases, the transferee judge may determine what portions of the existing court files would be necessary to managing the cases in the transferee district and request them directly from the transferor courts.

The vagaries of mail delivery being what they are, the transfer process can be marked by delay. The Clerk of the Panel historically recommended that the transferor court send the files via certified mail with return receipt requested in order to facilitate the delivery of the materials to the transferee court.[5] With the advent of electronic filing and case management, the transferee court can, as a practical matter, have immediate access to the files if needed.

Transfer creates special obligations on the courts for reporting the status of the dockets. The transferee court is required to open a new file upon receipt of the Panel's transfer order from the Panel, and the transferor court is required to close its files upon receipt of certified transfer order from the transferee court.[6] Once a file is opened in the transferee court, the proceedings take place in that civil action. The nature of those proceedings are discussed in greater detail in Chapter 8.

Transfer does not terminate the proceedings before the Panel. The Panel file remains “open” until all proceedings in the transferee court in any of the transferred actions or tag-along actions have been terminated.[7]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
See 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407. The statute is reprinted in § 3:19. See also Panel Rule 2.1(d).

The various means by which actions are disposed of could include remand, disposition in the transferee court on motion, settlement, and ultimate trial. Remand is discussed in Chapter 10, and these various potential dispositions in the transferee court are discussed in greater detail in §§ 9:18 to 9:25.
